Is there such a thing as "music for Instagram Reels"?

Greetings from Read Max HQ! In today‚Äôs newsletter, an examination of ‚ÄúBenson Boone‚Äù--whose song ‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚Äù you know very well even if you have never encountered the man‚Äôs name--and his relationship to the new FYP monoculture.

Before we start, a reminder: This newsletter exists because of the generosity of paying subscribers. I spend a lot of time reading, writing, thinking, listening to ‚ÄúBenson Boone,‚Äù etc., and I‚Äôm only able to treat this newsletter as a full-time job because people value what I do enough to pay for it. If you get something out of this newsletter--information, analysis, entertainment, a wry chuckle--please consider upgrading to a paid subscription for the low price of roughly one beer a month:

Like a lot of decadent coastal intellectuals, I had not heard of ‚ÄúBenson Boone‚Äù until this week, when the musician‚Äôs athletic Grammys performance of his song ‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚Äù hit the top of every platform‚Äôs algorithmic feed:

recordingacademy
A post shared by @recordingacademy

When I say I had not heard of ‚ÄúBenson Boone,‚Äù I meant I was not aware of the existence of the person in this video, who looks a bit like Paul Mescal if he was playing Freddie Mercury in a touring production of something called Bohemian Rhapsody: The Live Experience and also was taking 300mg of Wellbutrin daily.

The song, however--I know the song, even if I did not know its title until I began to write this post. (‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚Äù) I suppose until this week I assumed it didn‚Äôt even have a title--that it was a prototype, engineered in a remote Walgreens lab dedicated to building the perfect drugstore song. Boone seems like a nice guy and is a committed and dynamic performer; I wish him personal happiness. However I would be happy to never hear this song again in my life, or anything that sounds like it.

Where did I know the song? How did it know it, without knowing ‚ÄúBenson Boone‚Äù? Well, from Walgreens, to some extent--but more than anything, from short-form video apps. Many people on X (‚Äúthe Everything App‚Äù) noted the same thing:

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about this guy (amazing gymnast), but this song is always in instagram reels of influencer couples who are one Audi repo away from a murder-suicide at a Hyatt regency.‚Äù (@arod_twit)

‚Äúbenson boone makes music for reels where a lady is washing a baby pig in a sink‚Äù (@karlimarulli)

type of music that‚Äôs layered over ‚Äúhow my husbands üåΩ addiction ended our marriage, but now we co-parent our four autistic boys like nobody‚Äôs business‚Äù tiktoks (@violentlyepic)

One of the few beautiful things about the architecture of both TikTok and Instagram is that it‚Äôs possible to sort videos by music, and see most of the videos that use a particular song as their backting track. The obvious antecedent for ‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚Äù are the canned alt-rock epics of Imagine Dragons, a band whose music I associate with trailers to, like, late installments in Dreamworks Animation franchises I did not know existed but that make $300 million at the box office, and to whose frontman‚Äôs label Boone is signed. In a formal sense, Imagine Dragons‚Äô genre is sort of ‚Ä¶ ‚Äúpost-dubstep alt rock,‚Äù or something, but practically speaking I would classify them as ‚Äúretail-store anthemic,‚Äù an umbrella term that also includes AWOLNATION, Onerepublic, Sia, Hozier, arguably even Mumford & Sons, etc.

In normal circumstances I would consign ‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚Äù to the retail-store anthemic bin, or maybe the related genre ‚Äúcar commercial rock.‚Äù But while Boone obviously gets a lot of play in physical retail settings, not to mention BMW commercials, ‚Äúbig box store‚Äù is no longer the default environment to hear ‚Äúinoffensive anthemic adult contemporary.‚Äù (Nor, for that matter, given the rise of streaming and the displacement of network or cable television, are truck commercials.) Instead, Boone is more strongly associated with the quintessential contemporary American third space: The For You Page.

TikTok, for better or worse, has come to play a crucial hitmaking role in the music industry--an essential place for people to discover new music and artists. But usually the path is to get your track attached to a dance or trend. ‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚Äù managed to crack the top 10 songs on TikTok last year without any kind of associated challenge--not because it‚Äôs so unbelievably hooky it simply had to break through (though it is hooky), but because it‚Äôs perfectly engineered to soundtrack short-form videos.

What do I mean by that? ‚ÄúBeautiful Things‚Äù establishes a particular mood--bittersweet, positive, earnest, somewhat uplifting--that befits influencer-style content. It‚Äôs vaguely retro in a way that feels ‚Äútimeless‚Äù and unaffiliated to any particular moment or subculture. And, maybe most importantly, it‚Äôs built around a unmissable break or transition that lends itself to Capcut edits. (So much short-form video is structured as a before/after or a setup/punchline.)

This set of formal qualities comprises a burgeoning genre (such as it is) that I‚Äôd ‚ÄúFYPcore.‚Äù Other examples incldue Djo‚Äôs ‚ÄúEnd of Beginning‚Äù (which the TikToker above refers to as ‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm Back in Chicago‚Äù); the Dutch singer Sevdaliza‚Äôs song ‚ÄúAlibi‚Äù; and, I‚Äôd argue, Tommy Richman‚Äôs ‚ÄúMillion Dollar Baby,‚Äù though of course that one does have a dance to go with it. (‚ÄúGood 4 u‚Äù might qualify too?)

I say burgeoning because while the number of truly FYPcore songs right now is small, I fully expect adult contemporary songwriting to start shaping itself around the desires of the TikTok market. ‚ÄúMusic for Instagram Reels‚Äù is potentially a big business, and if you can‚Äôt will a viral dance out of your music, you can at least ensure that it will be the perfectly uplifting accompaniment to videos of your husband coming home from his job as a Bardominium salesman or ‚ÄúPOV: When you finally accept your trauma from being a middle child.‚Äù

One final thing I‚Äôve learned about Benson Boone, that ties it all together:

Here‚Äôs Zuck talking about Boone on the YouTube show Track Stars:

And here he his responding to Boone on Threads after the Grammys:

1

One thing that occurs to me about Benson Boone is that he, and the universe of short-form video he‚Äôs soundtracking, are thoroughly ‚Äúwest of the Rockies‚Äù phenomena. I don‚Äôt say this just because Boone is one of the most profoundly Mormon entertainers I‚Äôve ever seen--it‚Äôs also that the whole world of ‚Äúbarndominiums‚Äù and aging tattooed male Christian influencers for whom he serves as background music is effectively incomprehensible to my pathetic northeastern mind. Not that he‚Äôs unpopular over here on the other side of the continental divide, or that we don‚Äôt do gender reveals or big Coachella hats--but it‚Äôs clear these are imported cultural trends, and one consequence of social media is the increasing West-ification of the entire U.S.
